Back then all of us drank too much.
DISCOVER: A stately Victorian building...
The more in tune with the times we were, the more we drank.

And none of us contributed anything new.

When I came back from New York I was disgusted.
REVEAL: NICK CARRAWAY (37), unshaven, morbidly alcoholic.
Disgusted... with everyone, and everything... Only one man was exempt from my disgust.
REVEAL: A kind, elderly DOCTOR.
One man...? Mr. Carraway?
Gatsby...
Was he a friend of yours?
He was... the single most hopeful person I have ever met... And am ever likely to meet again. There was something about him...
Nick wanders slowly towards the window, remembering.
A sensitivity. He was like one of those machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away...
Where did you meet him?
Nick stops and stares out the window, haunted.
At a party. In New York.

Wall Street was luring the young and ambitious.

And I was one of them.

I rented a house twenty miles from the city, on Long Island.

I lived at West Egg...
Nick is moving in...
...in a forgotten grounds-keeper's cottage squeezed among the mansions of the newly rich.
Nick is unpacking...
To get started, I bought a dozen volumes on credit, banking and

All new to me...
And turns on the radio.
The stock market hit another record high today!

I got a dandy tip on Burlington; who's comin with me?!

Yes sir, of course nothing is one hundred percent. Well, I wouldn't go investing every penny. But...
Nick, still unpacking, eyes a mountain of unpacked books.
At Yale, I'd dreamed of being a writer.

But I gave all that up.
Nick emerges onto the porch, greeted by dazzling sunshine
With the sun shining and the great bursts of leaves on the trees, I planned to spend the summer studying.
Nick sits and places his bonds book in front of him...
And I probably would have--
When woman's shriek startles him...

Were it not for the riotous amusements that beckoned from beyond the walls of that colossal castle...
Through dense foliage Nick spies the mysterious spires an towers of the neighboring Gothic folly.
Owned by a gentleman I had not yet met, named...

Gatsby.
The Doctor concludes:
So... He was your neighbor?
My neighbor? No, Gatsby was-- Well-- If I think about it... The history of the summer really began the night I drove over to my cousin Daisy's for dinner...

She lived across the bay...

In old money East Egg.

Her husband was heir to one of America's wealthiest families.
Tom whacks the polo ball...
His name was Tom Buchanan.
The ball nearly hits one of Tom's gardeners...
When we were at Yale together he'd been a sporting star.

But now his glory days were behind him and he contented himself with... other affairs.

Shakespeare! How's the great American novel coming...?

Never heard of em.
Tom slaps Nick with irritating heartiness!
Hey! What say after dinner we go into town?
Catch up with the old wolf pack?
Big day on the new job tomorrow--
Nonsense! We're going.
Tom leads Nick down a grand hall lined with the trophies chronicle Tom's infinite sporting achievements.
First team, all-American!
Tom admires his own achievements.
You see? Made me who I am today.
Tom pulls his favorite trophy from the cabinet--
Here-- Forest Hills... I played the Prince of Wales. What a sissy!
Tom exchanges the trophy for a football.
Life's something you dominate Nick.
He pelts Nick with the ball--
If you're any good.
Nick fumbles as Tom charges him--
Ha-ha-ha!
Tom tackles Nick, knocking him back, through a pair of vaulting doors, and into...
A shimmering, sun-dazzled room in which enormous white curtains whip and snap in the breeze...
CLOSE ON: Nick, frozen, awestruck.
We hear the giggle of naughty children...
BOOM!!! As the French doors shut, and the curtains fall, beautiful white hand rises from behind the couch, and wit it, a low, thrilling voice...
Oh Nicky... Is that you my lovely?
Suddenly, 23 year old DAISY BUCHANAN, appears from over t back of the couch. Her bright eyes and passionate mouth a framed by a strawberry-blonde bob.
CLOSE ON: Daisy, captivating...
Daisy Buchanan. The golden girl. A breathless warmth flowed from her. A promise that there was no one else in the world she so wanted to see...
She whispers dramatically...
Do they miss me in Chicago?
Oh, yes. About a dozen people send their love.
How gorgeous.
They're absolutely in mourning... They're crying...
They're wailing...
They're screaming, they're shouting...
"Daisy Buchanan, we can't live without you!"
I'm p-paralyzed with happiness...!
Daisy takes Nick's hand and squeals with childish glee as drags him over the sofa and onto his back on the floor.
He stares up... And, a mysterious, athletic girl glares b This is 22 year old, JORDAN BAKER.
Jordan Baker; a very famous golfer.

She was the most frightening person I'd ever seen--
Nick rights himself and extends his hand.
I've seen your face on the cover of "Sporting Life". Nick Carraway...

But I enjoyed looking at her.

Gatsby?

Nicky... I heard a rumor, that you were getting married to a girl out west...

They have to be old so they die quickly...

Will have control of things.

I don't.

Got some woman?

Almost before Nick has grasped her meaning, the doors ban open and Tom and Daisy return to the table.
(a tense gayety) I just love seeing you at my table Nicky. You remind me of a rose, an absolute rose... Doesn't he?

Nicky, stay--
I have to work early.

Your daughter; I suppose she talks, and... eats, and everything?
Pammy? Oh yes...

All the bright precious things fade so fast...
And as a sad, sweet underscore plays, WE PUSH out over th water, and across the bay toward Gatsby's castle...
And they don't come back.

In the distance behind him we see headlights. It is Nick, pulling up at his bungalow.
Nick gets out of his car. He stops. Through the trees, he see The Man gazing intently across the bay.
When I arrived home I noticed that a figure had emerged on my neighbor's dock.
Nick goes closer, and watches The Man...
And something told me it was... Mr. Gatsby.
The Man reaches out--
He seemed to be... reaching toward something out there in the dark.
A green light on dock pulses in the distant darkness...
Nick, troubled...
The green light.
Green light?
Nick struggles with a painful memory...

I can't talk about THIS.
Then write about it.
Write?
Yes. Write.
Why would I do that?
After all, you said that writing brought you solace, once upon a time.
Yeah, well. It didn't bring anyone else much solace... I wasn't any good.
The Doctor offers Nick a pen; but Nick does not accept.
No one need ever read it. You can always burn it.
What would I write about?
Anything. Whatever you can't quite talk about; a memory; a thought; a place... Write it down.
CLOSE ON: Nick considering the challenge...
A place...
Slowly he takes the pen.

New York's dumping ground, half way between West Egg and the city...

...Where the burnt out coal that powered the booming, golden city was discarded by men who moved dimly and already crumbling through the powdery air.

...This fantastic farm was ever- watched by Dr. T. J. Eckleberg...

Tom had invited me to town, on the pretense of a lunch at the Yale Club....

Tom drags Nick from the moving train.
Come on--!

Trust me!
Wait a second would you!?
Dominate Nick! Dominate!

Hello Wilson! How's business?
I can't complain. When are you going to sell me that car?
I've got my man working on it.
Works pretty slow, don't he?
Maybe I'd better sell it somewhere else?
I don't mean that, I just...
Wilson's grovelling is terminated by the sound of chunky heels corkscrewing down stairs from above. All turn to se MYRTLE WILSON. Buxom. Smoldering. Elementally sensual.
If its business you're talking, you should be talking to me... (to her husband) Get some chairs why don't you; so somebody can sit down...
Myrtle smiles slowly and, walking through her husband as he were a ghost, shakes hands with Tom.
Hurry up!
Oh, sure... Sure...
Wilson hurries out back.
Mrs. Wilson... Nick Carraway.
A pleasure...
Nick's a writer...
Myrtle is completely uninterested.
I'm in bonds, actually...
(intently to Myrtle) Get on the next train.
(playing hard to get) Now...? Are we gettin' that dog?
Whatever you want. And you can call up your sister... (glancing to Nick) She'll like him...
Oh no, that's alright, I'm busy...
Catherine's said to be very good looking, by people who oughta know.
Really I can't...
(whispers to Nick) Do you want to embarrass Myrtle...? That's rude.
The muffled sounds of sex...

Hello...!

Nick Carraway.
Where're the kids?

Tom; I don't think-- Daisy's my--

Photography.

...He's a greasy little scumbag!

...I've got to get a massage, and a wave, and a collar for the dog, and one of those cute little ash-trays where you touch a spring, and a wreath with a black silk bow for mother's grave!

...and I was him too, looking up and wondering...

And I mean everyone: from every walk of life, from every corner of New York City, this kaleidoscopic carnival spilled through Gatsby's door...

Alongside gangsters and governors exchanging telephone numbers... Silent film stars... Broadway directors... Morality protectors... Casino collectors...

Hello.

CLOSE ON: Nick - his face drops.
Oh.. I'm very sorry-- I... I've had so much to drink...
The delirious opening chords of Tostoff's "History" coinc with a gorgeous explosion of fireworks in the night sky!
I thought you knew, old sport.
Gatsby smiles a dazzling smile; sound fades to a serene h
His smile was one of those rare smiles that you may come across four or five times in life. It seemed to understand you and believe in you just as you would like to be understood and believed in.
All at once the bubble bursts, a silver-haired, fifty-ish in an immaculate tail-suit, (HERZOG) leans into Gatsby.
Excuse me sir; Chicago on the wire.
Gatsby nods, but before he departs he smiles at Nick.
I'm trying out my new hydroplane in the morning. Want to go with me, old sport?
Nick shakes himself from his reverie.
What time?
Any time that suits you.
Gatsby turns, and catches for the first time, Jordan.
Lovely to see you Miss Baker.
He kisses her lightly on the hand.
If you need anything, just ask for it, old sport. I will rejoin you later... Excuse me.
As Nick watches Gatsby walk away, he whispers with amazem
I expected him to be...
Old and fat?
Well, yes; young men don't just drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island.
He told me once he was an Oxford man. However, I don't believe it...
Why not?
I don't know... I just don't believe he went there...
Jordan is interrupted by a voice.
I beg your pardon...
She and Nick jump to find Herzog suddenly beside them.
Miss Baker; Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you... Alone.
Me?
Yes, madame.
As Vladimir Tostoff's erotic, ominous chords build, Jorda crosses the now empty dance floor toward the silhouette o Gatsby in the library window...
Nick, unsettled, watches her go...

Alarmingly drunk girls sprawl at the feet of the grand pi Klipspringer plays, a weeping woman attempts to slur alon and as a dejected Nick passes them toward the front stair the library door opens, and Jordan emerges alone...
Seeing Nick, she rushes to him...
Nick! Nick! I've just heard the most shocking thing; it all makes sense...
Teddy and the other East Eggers accost Jordan.
Where have you been!? The car's waiting!
Jordan is dragged out the door... Nick, on tenterhooks follows, as Jordan calls back...
Simply amazing! It all makes sense. It all makes sense...
The night has devolved into drunken mayhem as cars jam th driveway and intoxicated guests search for their vehicles
Nick chases Jordan down the marble stairs.
What makes sense...?
Everything... But here I am tantalizing you...
The East Eggers and Jordan pile into their limousine. Jor a mysterious smile as she leans out the window.
And I swore I wouldn't tell.
But...
Nick. I'm sorry, I swore I wouldn't tell.
The car takes off and Nick is left staring; mystified...
A voice startles him.
Sorry to keep her from you, old sport. Don't forget; we're going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning.
Herzog appears behind Gatsby.
Philadelphia on the phone, sir.
Gatsby nods, then smiles that intoxicating smile.
Good night, old sport...
Good night. Thank you.
Gatsby nods warmly, and turns inside.
As Nick walks away he is confronted by a bizarre scene: a crowd gathers around a COUPГ‰, resting on its side in a d
SUDDENLY! Owl Eyes pops from the wreck. He leers drunkenl
Whazza matter!? We run outta gas!?
The beep of a horn catches Nick's attention. Jordan, lean out of the window of her car as it sweeps away, calls to
Come and see me... We'll have tea! I'm in the phone-book!
Nick waves, smiles, and cuts across the lawn.
CLOSE ON: Nick. As he reaches the stone-pass separating h yard from Gatsby's, he stops; a familiar feeling...
High up in the window, the shadowy figure of Gatsby stand phone pressed to his ear, watching Nick. After a moment, raises his hand in formal farewell.
We rode in the hydroplane... And I attended two more of his parties, even made use of his beach. But I soon realized that I knew absolutely nothing about Gatsby at all, until...
Nick is eating breakfast, studying bonds, when his glass orange juice begins to rattle and shake.
Puzzled, Nick hurries to the window...
Gatsby's yellow Duesenberg hurtles up Nick's drive and sk to a stop.
Nick emerges to his porch.
Gatsby leaps out!
Its pretty isn't it, old sport...? Haven't you seen it before? Its all a custom job. Supercharged engine. Get dressed... We're having lunch!
The Duesenberg whips and winds along a tree-lined road... Gatsby, beyond nervous, drives with reckless intensity.
Ah... well... Ah... Look here, old sport... What's your opinion of me, anyhow?
My... opinion?
Yes, yes, your opinion!
Gatsby yanks the wheel; Nick hangs on for dear life!
I don't want you to get the wrong impression from all those bizarre accusations you must be hearing. A pack of lies I assure you. You've heard the stories...?

I'll tell you God's truth. God's truth about myself! (raises right hand) I am the son of some very wealthy people from the Middle-West; sadly, all dead now... I was brought up in America, but educated at Oxford; because all my ancestors have been educated there for many years. You see, it's a... a family tradition.
As Gatsby's speech continues at breakneck speed... Nick's V.O. fades up.
The way he spoke... No wonder people thought he was lying...
After that I lived like a young Prince in all the capitals of Europe!
Europe?
Barrelling around a blind turn, Gatsby wrenches at the wh and maniacally overtakes a truck laden with farmhands...

Yes, Europe! Paris; Venice; Rome; Vienna, Zurich, Helsinki... Collecting jewels, chiefly rubies, hunting big game, painting, a little, things for myself mostly, and trying to forget something very sad that happened to me long ago...

text: Gatsby hasn't stopped for breath...
Then came the war, old sport...
Just when I thought it couldn't be any more fantastical...
It was a great relief and I tried very hard to die, but I seemed to bear an enchanted life...
He became a war hero, single- handedly defeating the German army!
CLOSE ON: Gatsby. He speaks with sudden, subdued emotion.

In the Argonne Forest I took my machine gun detachment so far forward... We were outnumbered five to one. There was a half mile gap on either side of us where the infantry couldn't advance. We stayed there two days and two nights, 130 men with only 16 Lewis guns...
Something catches Nick's eye...
NICK'S POV: Myrtle Wilson pumps gas outside Wilson's Gara
...When the infantry came up at last they found the insignia of 3 German divisions among the piles of the dead.
SCREEECHHH!!! Gatsby slams to halt at the train crossing!
I was promoted to Major and every Allied government gave me a decoration; even Montenegro! Little Montenegro down on the Adriatic Sea.
SLAM! A medal is suddenly in Nick's lap.
Here! That's the one from Montenegro.
It looks authentic.
Turn it.
Major Jay Gatsby. For Valor Extraordinary.
That's right.
SLAP! A photograph joins the medal.
Here's another thing that I always carry. A souvenir of my Oxford days; the man on my left is now the Earl of Doncaster.
CLOSE ON: The photograph. Young men in blazers loaf in fr of Oxford College. Gatsby stands with a cricket bat in ha
What could I say...? The photograph was undoubtedly authentic. Could it all be true?
DING! The gate lifts. And as Gatsby peels out, towards Ne York, he continues...

But don't take my word for it. At lunch, I'm going to introduce you to one of New York's most distinguished businessmen; my friend, Mr. Meyer Wolfsheim, who will confirm all I've told you, and vouch for my good character...
Gatsby weaves between the pylons of the elevated highway.
I'm sure that's not necessary...
Gatsby wheels to Nick, smiling with charming intensity.

Oh but it is though...! You see, I thought you ought to know something about my life. I... I don't want you to think I'm just some... some nobody. You see, old sport, I'm going to make a very big request of you today.
A big request?
Yes. Yes... Miss Baker will explain everything when you take her to tea this afternoon.
(caught off guard) Jordan...? What's she got to do with it?
Oh, I assure you it's nothing underhand. Miss Baker's an honest sportswoman; she'd never do anything that wasn't alright...
RRIIIRRRAA! A shrieking police siren! Before Gatsby can continue, a MOTORCYCLE COP pulls alongside.
Pull over!!! Pull over to the curb!
All right, old sport! Alright.
Without slowing, Gatsby takes a card from his pocket...
Right you are... Know you next time, Mr. Gatsby. Excuse me!
The cop peels off; and the Duesenberg, carrying an absolu mystified Nick, rockets towards the Queensboro Bridge!
One of your old Oxford pals?
Well... actually, I was able to do the Commissioner a favor once; he sends a Christmas card every year.
I imagine he'll be at lunch too...
By the time we reached the bridge I was impossibly confused...
Nick turns to see: A Rolls Royce in which two stylish AFR AMERICAN MEN and a WOMAN haughtily quaff champagne. They driven by a WHITE CHAUFFEUR.
An orchestral melody surges...

I didn't know what to think... But the city seen from the Queensboro Bridge is always the city seen for the first time, in its first wild promise of all the mystery and the beauty in the world. Anything can happen now that we've slid over this bridge, I thought; anything at all...

As the orchestra builds, Gatsby's car shoots into Manhatt through Times Square and beneath the famous advertisement the man in the Arrow shirt. We follow, sweeping high over skyscrapers. The Duesenberg pulls up on the street below.
SUDDENLY THE CAMERA PLUMMETS with startling velocity...
Even Gatsby could happen...
BAAAAM! A fat beat kicks as we explode through a grate, i
The sweaty grind of music shakes the air. On stage a pian THE PROFESSOR, bangs out a sizzling tune!
