text: DISCOVER: Nick and Gatsby entering the cramped shop...
In the center of the room a tall, distinguished, grey-bea man in an exquisitely cut suit, and with gold rings on ev finger, is having a beard trim. This, is MEYER WOLFSHEIM.
Ah my boy...!
They embrace.
Meyer, Meyer...
You smell so good.
Mr. Carraway; my friend, Mr. Wolfsheim.
Gatsby guides Nick and Wolfsheim toward the back of the s
A wonderful pleasure, Mr. Carraway. I know all about you.
Really?
Of course! Mr. Gatsby is always talking about you.
Gatsby raps a coded knock on a hidden door at the back of shop. The door slides open, the rumble of music pours out
Come, join us for a little lunch...
Gatsby ushers Wolfsheim and Nick down narrow creaking sta through the crowd and into the smoke-filled speakeasy...
ECU: Nick, taking in his NEW, SEEDY surroundings.
(whispers to Gatsby) Tell Walter Chase; "he shuts his mouth or he doesn't get a penny..."
We'll talk about that later...
The HEAD WAITER appears.
Highballs, Mr. Gatsby?
Yes, highballs it is. (points to Nick) You take good care of my friend here!
A portly man of obvious stature, surrounded by scantily c flappers, yells from a corner booth.
Hey Jay...! You're under arrest!!!
Gatsby smiles and tips his hat.
You be careful now. You're turning into a real Jazz-Hound Commissioner.
See, that's the Commissioner back there.
Gatsby, the king here, greets patrons high and low...
He sees SENATOR GULICK at the craps table.
You be careful at those tables now Senator!
Of course! I'll put a bet on for you Jay!
Waiters clear a front row table - best seat in the house Gatsby helps Wolfsheim to his. Wolfsheim eyes the girls o the stage.
Gatsby flashes Nick a charming smile.
Shall we order? (to the waiter) Lobster tails all round.
They decorate it with truffle slices and fine herbs. Very artistic.
Wolfsheim glances to Gatsby, and then turns again to Nick
So... How is the bond business Mr. Carraway?
It's fine, thank you.
I understand you're looking for a
No, no. This isn't the man. This is the friend I told you about.
Oh! Beg your pardon, I had a wrong man.
Woldsheim pats Nick on the back, unsettling him further..
Gatsby, a quick glance to his watch and Wolfsheim, jumps
Now, if you'll excuse me. I have to make THAT call. (gesturing to Nick) Meyer, do you mind?
Gatsby leaving Nick and Wolfsheim alone.

Gatsby! What a gentleman! From one of the finest families in the Midwest... Sadly all dead now. Let me tell you, when I made the pleasure of Mr. Gatsby's acquaintance just after the war, I knew I had discovered a man of fine breeding. A war hero! Such... medals. And, an Oggsford man. Oggsford College in England. You know Oggsford?
I've heard of it...
Then you would know that a man like that can be trusted. With a friend, with someone like you, he would never so much as look at your wife...
I'm not... married.
But you work on Wall Street, right?
Yes...
Nick studies Wolfsheim, noticing an oddity about his outf
Looking at my tiepin?
CLOSE ON: The pin.
Finest specimen of human molars...
Before Nick can recover, Gatsby suddenly returns.
Gentlemen. Everything alright...?
Oh, yes... We were just talking about other people's wives...
(taking his seat) Other people's wives? Ah... I see.
Gatsby looks to Wolfsheim.
Other people's wives... Meyer?
Wolfsheim nods, smiles, and checks out the dancing girls.
Well, my work here is done. I'll leave you gentlemen to talk about your sports and your women...
Wolfsheim follows his favorite dancer off...
You'll have to excuse him... In his old age, he's prone to "digress..." He's a regular around here; a real denizen of Broadway...
Who is he anyhow?
Meyer? He's a gambler.
Over Nick and Gatsby's shoulders is Wolfsheim, mingling w the ladies; but occasionally glancing in their direction.
An actor?
Meyer? No. He's the man who fixed the 1919 World Series.
Fixed it?
Fixed it.
How did he manage that?
He just... saw the opportunity, I suppose. He's a very smart man. (tries to change subject) Now, old sport, about Miss Baker, and that request we spoke of...
Before Gatsby can go on, Tom Buchanan looms over the tabl
Hey Nick! Nick! Where've you been!? Daisy's furious you haven't called up.
Nick and Gatsby stand.
This is Mr. Gatsby, Mr. Buchanan.
CLOSE ON: Gatsby. With strange intensity he offers his ha
I'm so very, very... delighted to make your acquaintance.
Tom turns back to Nick.
I wouldn't have expected to find you in this temple of virtue.
I'm having lunch with Mr. Gats--
Nick turns, but inexplicably, Gatsby is gone.
PUSH TOWARD: Nick, surprise rising into anger...
Jordan is perched at an elegant table, overlooking Times Square and the advertisement of the man in the beautiful Arrow shirts.
DISCOVER: Nick, frustrated, dodging the fashionable and famous...
I'm looking for Ms. Baker. Yes. The famous sporting star. The golfer... There... I've spotted her.
Nick comes to an abrupt halt in front of Jordan.
What game are you and Gatsby playing at!?
An immaculate MAITRE'D offers Nick a chair.
Will the gentleman be joining?
One moment please--
Please, Nick, sit down. This is a polite restaurant.
As Nick's frustration and Jordan's embarrassment grow--
It's all very strange. He picks me up in his fancy yellow car... And he's going on and on and on about his life and the war and rubies and Oxford and... What is--
If you'll just have a seat--
What is this big request!?
Nick--! He just wants you to invite Daisy to tea.
Tea? (not what Nick expected) Daisy...? And Gatsby...?
Nick sits...
Why?
Well... I don't know quite where to start. You see... I met Gatsby, five years ago, in Louisville...
TIGHT ON: Golf shoes biting into soft, green grass.
It was the day I got my new English golf shoes.
WIDE: A row of fancy Louisville homes - red, white and bl bunting "tut, tutting" in the breeze - are set along a beautiful, green stretch of park.
Daisy was by far the most popular girl with the Officers from Camp Taylor...
Across the road, 18 YEAR OLD DAISY is perched in the fron seat of her flashy white roadster, beaming, happy...
One of them was in the car with her.
Beside Daisy REVEAL: A handsome lieutenant: YOUNG JAY GAT
It was Gatsby. And the way he looked at her...
The silhouettes of Jordan and Nick, leaned close, are lit magnificently against the beaded lights of the city...
Is the way all girls want to be looked at.
Their eyes meet; a conspiring flicker.
So what happened?
Well, I don't know...
Gatsby leads his men on a heroic charge out of the trench
Gatsby was sent off to war...
A MASSIVE EXPLOSION rocks the battlefield!
But when the war ended... For some unknown reason, Gatsby couldn't return...
A year later, Tom Buchanan of Chicago swept in and stole her away...
An exquisite string of pearls coils around Daisy's neck.
He gave her a string of pearls worth $350,000.
REVEAL: Tom, tightening the clasp.
But, the morning of the wedding, Daisy received a letter...
On the bed, Daisy, hysterical, clutches a bottle in one h and a letter in the other.
Tell them Daisy's changed her mind!
Daisy! Please, everyone's waiting!
Daisy reaches for the pearls around her neck...
Give them back!!
Suddenly! Daisy tears the pearls and hurls them; they exp into a hundred shimmering pieces against the hard wood fl
CUT TO: A set of stern, white heels clicking down the hal
REVEAL: Daisy's hard-mouthed MOTHER.
What on earth is going on in here!?
her mother's eyes land on the bottle, and then the letter
PUSH IN: The last line of the letter reads: Love, Jay.
Leave me alone!
Jordan, run the bath! Now!
In the bath, Daisy's grips the letter in her trembling ha
What was in the letter?
A deep breath, a last look, and then, Daisy opens her han
The letter comes to pieces like snow.
I don't know. She wouldn't tell me.
But before the letter disappears completely we read one m line: "The truth is..."
Daisy and Tom, newly married, pose for photos.
Anyways, that day, at five o'clock, Daisy Faye married Tom Buchanan with more pomp and circumstance than Louisville had ever seen...
Jordan and Nick stroll beneath the soaring electric signs
After the honeymoon, I saw them in Santa Barbara. It was touching, actually...
I'd never seen a girl so in love with her husband.
A week later, Tom crashed his car. The girl with him was a chambermaid at the Santa Barbara Hotel. It got into all the papers...
As Jordan and Nick approach the curb, waiting for a cab, turns to Jordan; he's struck by a... sudden, puzzled thou
It's a strange coincidence, isn't it? Gatsby's house being just across the bay...
Jordan whirls round--
It's no coincidence. He bought that house to be near her, he threw all those parties hoping she'd wander in one night. He constantly asked about Daisy... I was the first one who knew her.
Nick takes this in; as if seeing Gatsby for the first tim
All that for a girl he hasn't seen in five years...? And now he just wants me to have her for tea...?
The modesty of it.
Kind of takes your breath away, doesn't it?
A cab pulls up, and Nick opens the door...
Jordan slides in...
Evening sweethearts! Where to?
Long Island, please.
And you think I should? I mean, does Daisy want to see Gatsby?
(a stern whisper) She's absolutely not to know. You are just supposed to invite her over so he can "happen to drop by."
CLOSE ON: Nick, unsure...
I remember feeling torn. Was it right to bring my cousin Daisy, a married woman, together with a man I hardly knew?
As Nick wonders, the taxi floats across Times Square, und the cool eyes of the man in the Arrow shirt...
Nick's taxi pulls past Gatsby's mansion, ablaze with ligh
When I returned home, Gatsby's was lit, from tower to cellar, as if for another wild party. But... There wasn't a sound.
As Nick's taxi groans away, Gatsby appears striding throu the illuminated trees toward Nick.
Your place looks like the World's Fair... or Coney Island!
Ah, does it? I've... I've just been glancing into some rooms... Let's go to Coney Island, old sport, we can take my car--
It's too late tonight.
Or we can take a plunge in the swimming pool? I haven't made use of it all summer...
I must go to bed...
Gatsby looks crestfallen. Nick puts him out of his misery
Happy to do it. Jay-- I'm going to call Daisy and invite her to tea.
Oh, that's alright. I don't want to put you to any trouble...
What day would suit you?
What day would suit you...? I don't want to put you to any trouble...
Day after tomorrow alright?
Day after tomorrow? Well, I'd... I'd want to get the grass cut.
They both look at the grass - there is a sharp line where Nick's ragged lawn ends and Gatsby's manicured one begins
There's another little thing... I thought-- Look here, old sport-- You don't make much money, do you?
Not really.
If you'll pardon my... You see, I carry on a little business on the side - a sort of sideline - you understand what I'm saying right? You're selling bonds, aren't you, old sport?
Trying to.
Well, this might interest you... It happens to be a rather confidential sort of thing... But you might pick up a nice bit of money.
I've got my hands full.
Gatsby's face falls.
You wouldn't have to do any business with Wolfsheim. I assure you.
No, no, no... Its a favor Jay. Just a favor.
Nick's sincerity disarms Gatsby; a tiny, embarrassed nod.
Happy to do it.
A favor?
Yes.
As if no one has ever done him a favor before in his life
Ah, right, right... Goodnight.
Goodnight.
With this, Gatsby turns and strolls back toward his blazi castle. Nick's gaze falls upon the unkempt lawn. He smile
TOP SHOT: An enormous mower clatters through frame, carvi Nick's unkempt lawn into a fresh, broad, band of green.
REVEAL: An army of gardnders giving Nick's lawn and garde make-over, fresh paint, new flowers, trimmed hedges...
Heavy rain now falls.

Gatsby, dressed in white flannel suit, silver shirt, and tie, leads a dozen umbrella-holding servants across the l Herzog holds an umbrella over Gatsby; the other servants shelter extravagant floral arrangements in crystal vases.
Nick watches the parade through his window, opening his d just as Gatsby arrives; the servants continue inside.
On the porch, Gatsby looks around distractedly.
One of the papers said they thought the rain would stop about four. I think it was the Journal...
An awkward beat.
The grass looks fine.
Grass?
Gatsby looks at Nick without really comprehending, or see
What Grass?
TIGHT ON: A mantelpiece clock, ticking in the tense silen
WIDER: The room is crowded with absurdly extravagant flor arrangements. Nick sits watching as Gatsby intensely pace The silence stretches, and stretches... Finally...
Have you got everything you need?
Perhaps more flowers?
I think they did a fine job, don't you?
Beautiful.
You think it's too much?
I think it's what you want.
I think so too... She'll be impressed, won't she old sport?
I am.
With this, Gatsby straightens his suit, sits, and hurried checks his watch. Another long silence...
PUSH IN ON: Gatsby... SUDDENLY! He leaps to his feet!
I can't wait all day. I'm leaving!
Don't be silly. It's just two minutes to four...
But Gatsby heads for the door...
Nobody's coming to tea. It's too late!
BEEEEEP! Gatsby glimpses Daisy's Rolls Royce arriving out front, and turns to Nick, flushed with fresh panic.
It's her.
PUSH IN ON GATSBY: Mind racing...
Daisy's chauffeur-driven Rolls pulls up in the muddy driv
As Nick assists Daisy from the car...
Is this absolutely where you live, my dearest one?
She looks at him with a mysterious smile.
Why did I have to come alone? Are you in love with me?
That's the secret of Carraway Castle.
Tell your chauffeur to go far away.
Come back in an hour, Ferdie!
His name is Ferdie.
Daisy continues ahead into the living room.
Nick hangs back and listens hopefully to Daisy's reaction discovering Gatsby. He smiles as he hears a delighted...
Oh--! Oh, my goodness. I... I can't believe it. You-- Did you ransack a greenhouse?
He is in love with me...
Nick enters, but is shocked to discover that Gatsby is no there. Daisy's merely been admiring the flower display...
That's funny.
What's funny?
KNOCK. KNOCK. Someone is at the door.
One moment...
Nick opens the door.
Gatsby, pale as death and soaked, glares miserably at Nic
What are you doing?
Without a word, Gatsby stalks past him, into...
Daisy, her back to the door, is still marvelling at the flowers. Then she turns. Sees Gatsby. A sharp intake of breath...
The reunited lovers stand, staring at each other for a lo surreal, moment of disbelief. Gatsby, eyes locked to Dais is drowning in emotion. Daisy finally manages an artifici choking murmur.
I'm certainly glad to see you again.
Gatsby's face is flushed; the veins stand out on his neck his lips spasm in a hopeless attempt to speak.
Finally, he finds words...
I'm... certainly glad to see you as well.
Their hearts pound - the tension excruciating.
EEEEKKK! The scream of a boiling kettle OFF SCREEN breaks
Gatsby reclines uncomfortably against the mantelpiece. Hi elbow rests near the mantelpiece CLOCK. Daisy sits opposi frozen on the edge of a chair.
The rattle of the tea tray as Nick enters only contribute the already unbearable tension. Gatsby manages to murmur.
We've met before...
SUDDENLY the CLOCK tilts at the pressure of Gatsby's elbo
And falls! And breaks!
Ah... sorry...
He clumsily tries to repair the clock; but drops it again
It's an old... clock.
(desperate for small talk) Lovely though. A lovely... clock.
Gatsby finally manages to set the clock back on the mantl
Gatsby takes a seat.
A long silent beat.
We haven't met for many years.
(an automatic reflex) Five years next November.
The precision of Gatsby's answer is acutely embarrassing.
Tea?
Thank you old sport.
Darling thank you.
Nick pours; and they all sit stiffly, sipping their tea.
A long, terrible silence...
Suddenly Nick stands.
I just need to... pop into town.
Town...?
The village; I'll be right back.
As Nick leaves, Gatsby follows.
I've got to speak to you...!
Wildly following Nick, Gatsby whispers miserably:
Oh, God! This is a mistake, a terrible, terrible mistake...
You're just embarrassed, that's all... Daisy's embarrassed too.
She's embarrassed?
Just as much as you are.
Don't talk so loud!
You're acting like a little boy! You're rude. Daisy's in there all alone and...
Gatsby raises his hand, looks at Nick reproachfully, and heads back into the living room.
Nick runs for a TREE whose leaves shield against the rain
Looking over my story so far, I'm reminded that for the second time that summer...
WIDE: Nick beneath the tree looks tiny, and very alone.
I was guarding other people's secrets.
LATER. Nick re-enters, bedraggled, rain-soaked.
Once again I was within...
He tries to get Gatsby and Daisy's attention, to no avail The lovers are completely and totally absorbed in each ot
And without...
Nick bangs pots in the sink - still nothing.
He clears his throat:
Its... stopped raining.
Daisy turns; a radiant smile. Every vestige of embarrassm between Daisy and Gatsby is gone. Gatsby literally glows.
Yes, it has...
Hasn't it?
He stands, walks to the window and looks out across the b
What do you think of that, Daisy? Come look.
Daisy joins Gatsby and they step out onto the porch toget
Look. Its my house. Just there across the bay...
Gatsby and Daisy's eyes meet.
I know. I have the same view from my place.
Where's your place?
Gatsby turns back to Nick.
Nick, I want you and Daisy both to see my house. I'd like to show her around.
Are you sure you want me to come?
Absolutely, old sport. Absolutely.
Servants swing open ivy-covered gates...
I had the gates brought in from a castle in Normandy.
REVEAL: Gatsby's castle glistening in the sunlight.
CLOSE ON: Daisy. A delighted cry.
Oh, Jay...!? Its so grand!
Do you like it?
I love it...! But how do you live here all alone?
I don't. I keep it always full of interesting, celebrated people...
As Daisy runs ahead, Gatsby murmurs to Nick.
My house looks well doesn't it? See how the whole front catches the light like that?
Daisy yells back...
Come on you two! I want the royal tour!
Gatsby has transformed into a good-natured show-off, hurr Nick and Daisy through a maze of fantastical gardens, pas magnificent fountains and into his castle...
Gatbsy shows off his brand new orange-juicer.
You must understand, I like all things that are modern.
Daisy readies a cocktail shaker beneath the spout of the giant silver orange juice machine.
If you press this button here, the oranges shoot through here, are crushed there... The juice of 200 oranges extracted in one hour...!
Gatsby presses, the machine groans and juice splashes out
Daisy, Nick and Gatsby drunkenly drive golf balls out tow the bay. Nick films on the world's first home-camcorder..
Its a remarkable little camera-- latest design.
While, nearby, a butler in a boat stands watch over a spinning gramophone and bottles of champagne...
You do know, I'm a champion golfer, don't you? Here, I'll show you how its done.
CRACK! Daisy cuts a marvelous swing, snapping a club in t
She falls into Gatsby arms...
Nick films...
She looks like she could be on the cover of Vogue, don't you think...?
Gatsby and Nick trail behind Daisy, crossing the ballroom
Daisy, champagne in hand, spots the soaring ballroom orga
Oh...! Its beautiful.
Its a custom Wurlitzer.
Can anyone play it?
Klipspringer can. (to his footmen) Someone wake Ewing!
Daisy twirls round, overjoyed...
Music! And we can dance all night!
Ewing's a symphonic genius, he can play anything...!
Daisy runs up the stairs and calls down...
Then I demand a Charleston!
Gatsby gazes up after Daisy, and confides in Nick...
(as if in a dream) She makes it look so splendid, don't you think old sport?
Nick and Daisy follow Gatsby into the bedroom...
Gatsby bounds ahead, starting up a spiral stair... He thr open a massive cabinet, revealing a prism of suits, dress gowns, watches and ties.
I've got a man in England who buys me clothes...!
He playfully tosses Daisy a boater-hat...
Something for the lady...
Then he begins yanking down shirts and tossing them over rail to Daisy...
I've never seen anything like it!
He sends over a selection at the beginning of each season...
Jay!
With ever-increasing enthusiasm!
These are silk! Linen! Indian flannel! Egyptian cotton!
Daisy, intoxicated, leaps on the bed, arms outstretched..
No, Jay... you'll ruin them!
Nicky! He's a madman!
More and more and more shirts float down...
The rumble of distant thunder.
CLOSE ON: Daisy. TIME SLOWS AS shirts flutter, like giant snowflakes, down toward her. Slowly, quietly, her mirth transforms to sobs... She hides her face in shirts...
Gatsby eases down the stairs and nestles beside Daisy, ta her tear-streaked face in his hands...
What is it?
It's just... It makes me sad, because...
Daisy glances in Nick's direction...
Why?
...because...
A suspended moment; Daisy is incapable of speaking her he
Five lost years struggled on Daisy's lips. But all she could manage was...
It's just... Because I've never seen such beautiful shirts before.
If it wasn't for the mist we could see the green light...
What green light?
The one that burns all night at the end of your dock.
As Gatsby and Daisy stare out across the bay...

Possibly, it had occurred to Gatsby that the colossal significance of that light had vanished forever. Now, it was once again just a green light on a dock. His count of enchanted objects had diminished by one.
Nick, impelled to remind Daisy and Gatsby of his presence emerges from the shadows and descends the spiral staircas
He holds a photo of an elderly man in yachting costume...
Who's this? Your father?
No, no.. That's Mr. Dan Cody, old sport... He's dead now. He used to be my best friend years ago.
Daisy joins Nick at the bottom of the steps. In the photo with Cody, also in yachting costume, is a young Gatsby...
You never told me you had a pompadour... or a yacht.
Gatsby hastily plucks a scrapbook from a row on his desk.
I want to show you something... Look, here's a lot of clippings, about you.
They admire a scrapbook together.
You saved my letters...
This was my first photo of you.
As Daisy flips through and pulls out an old letter of her we hear her reading the letter in abstract VOICEOVER:
We cant lose each other and let all this glorious love end in nothing. Come home, I'll be here waiting and hoping, for every long dream of you to come true... Come home Jay...
BBBRRRNNNGGG! The phone shrills.
Excuse me.
Gatsby crosses the room, snatches up the receiver, and tu away... He lowers his voice.
Well I can't talk now old sport...
As the timbre of Gatsby's voice darkens we PUSH CLOSER.
I said a small town.
ECU: Gatsby's eyes narrow.
He must know what a small town is.
BOOOOMMM! A storming wind bangs open the French windows!
As Nick moves to shut them, he glimpses Gatsby...
Well, he's no use to us if Detroit is his idea of a small town...
Gatsby rings off abruptly, and catches Nick's eye - a ten moment - which Gatsby banishes with that electrifying smi
We hear the distant, jaunty sounds of a pipe organ...
Ah, Klipspringer! He must be awake! Shall we?
Daisy, wearing a flowing robe and heels, dances a Charles with Nick.
An elaborate picnic, complete with candelabras and a moun of cushions, is laid out on the floor. There, Gatsby sits looking on, flush with joy.
Slowly though, Gatsby's expression turns introspective. A watches Daisy dance, memories flood back to him...

head_text.subj: AN ARRAY OF MEMORIES AND IMAGES DISSOLVE ONE INTO THE OTH

text: Gatsby and Daisy, five years ago, about to kiss; a hand- written letter; a gathering storm; the green light...
Hundreds of candles flicker in patterns. As a slow, melancholic waltz plays, Gatsby and Daisy dance, enraptured...
I wish I had done everything on earth with you. All my life.
Gatsby holds her closer.
I wish that it could always be like this...
It will be...
Across the room, Nick, exhausted and drunk and unnoticed, stands to leave. At the ballroom doors he turns back and glimpses Gatsby and Daisy, in a universe all their own...
If only it had been enough for Gatbsy, just to hold Daisy...
The towering doors close.
Gatsby stands at his window, staring into the night.
But he had a grand vision for his life, and Daisy's part in it.
Nick is writing at his desk...
It wasn't until the end of that summer, on the last night I saw Gatsby, that he told me of the life he had dreamt for himself since he was a boy...
Nick stops his reading, and, very slowly, admits...
You see doctor... Gatsby's real name was... James Gatz.
PUSH TOWARD: A dilapidated hut, shrouded in a storm of du
His parents were dirt-poor farmers from North Dakota...
DISCOVER: YOUNG GATZ, barefoot, at a dusty desk, surround by tattered books, strange charts, and lists. He is practicing his signature...
But he never accepted them as his parents at all.
Young Gatz turns from his writing, and looks through a ho in the roof towards the infinite heavens...
In his own imagination, he was... a Son of God...
CLOSE ON: The little boy looks up at CAMERA.
Destined for future glory...
The silhouette of TEENAGE GATZ, now 16 years old, disappe into the hills...
Chasing this destiny, a sixteen year old Gatz ran far, far away.
CLOSE ON: A handsome 17 year old YOUNG GATSBY, in a torn jersey and dirty canvas pants, rowing with all his might.
One afternoon, off the coast of Lake Superior, he spotted a yacht in peril...
Young Gatsby lets the row boat drift close to a magnifice yacht. Wind is whipping whitecaps on the bay.
He rowed out and rescued the vessel, and its captain, alcoholic millionaire Dan Cody...
The bleary face of DAN CODY appears at the yacht's railin
Whadzamatta...?
Cody is very drunk. Young Gatsby calls urgently.
Sir! The shoal here's real bad, this wind could drag you onto it...
Cody waves a dismissive arm...
Whaderathinkyerdoin..., old sport?
He collapses, dead drunk.
PUSH IN: On Young Gatsby; a plan forming...
This was his opportunity, and he seized it.
Springing into action, he clambers onto the yacht.
I decided right then and there to call myself: Jay Gatsby.
Young Gatsby hoists the sail as the storm rages around hi
He sailed the yacht out of danger - and into his future...
A perfect sunny day. Young Gatsby and Cody are sailing.
Gatsby showed skill and ambition, and for five years they sailed the world...
He was alright, old Dan, he taught me everything...
Young Gatsby, now transformed, models a suit in the mirro
How to dress, act, and speak like a gentleman...
He looks squarely at himself, and repeats a mantra.
Gatsby. Jay Gatsby. A pleasure to meet you, sir. Gatsby. Jay Gatsby. Gatsby. Jay Gatsby.
Young Gatsby stands at the bow, as the yacht cut across t clear blue ocean... He turns to Cody and calls...
She looks well, doesn't she...!? Old sport.
HIGH AND WIDE: The yacht sails toward the golden sun...

Gatsby hoped to inherit Cody's fortune... But when Cody died, Gatsby was cheated out of his inheritance by Cody's family... He'd been left with an ability to play the gentleman, but he was once again dirt poor.
Piles and piles of New York City newspapers swirl rapidly TOWARD CAMERA, and we read their headlines:
By midsummer Gatsby was front page news...
A final newspaper COVERS FRAME:
We PUSH TOWARD the paper and DISSOLVE TOWARD:
Another glittering party.
Where did the money comes from?
FADE IN: Decadent, grotesque images of drunken revellers.
That's what all of New York wanted to know. And it was the same question on Tom's mind when he accompanied Daisy to one of Gatsby's glittering parties...
DISCOVER: Gatsby leading Tom, Daisy and Nick to the top o the terrace stairs.
We've got a great band here. Have a look around... Excuse me...
He turns briefly to talk to Senator Gulick...
(mutters to Daisy) A lot of these newly rich people are just filthy bootleggers.
Not Gatsby. He's a businessman.
Hah! A businessman...
He owned a lot of drug stores.
Gatsby gracefully introduces Senator Gulick to the group.
May I introduce Senator Gulick? This is Mr. Carraway and Mrs. Buchanan...
Delighted...
And Mr. Buchanan... (a moment's hesitation) The polo player.
Oh no. Not me.
(shaking hands, nods) Always a pleasure to meet a Buchanan.
Gatsby bids the Senator farewell, while Tom glowers to Da
I'd rather not be the polo player.
Oh Tom... You should be proud of your achievements.
(to the group) May I show you around?
He guides them down the stairs...
You must see the faces of a lot of people you've heard of.
Absolutely!
We don't go around very much. I don't think I recognize a single person...
Perhaps you know that lady there?
Gatsby indicates a lovely, orchid of a woman: MARLENE MOO the silent film star.
(taking Gatsby's arm) Its Marlene Moon... I adore her pictures...
As Gatsby leads Daisy, we catch Tom repeating to Nick...
I'd really rather not be the polo player...
Tom, Daisy, Nick and Gatsby sit an elaborately conceived dinner table, watching the band...
These things excite me so...
Gatsby turns to Tom...
I believe we've met somewhere before, Mr. Buchanan. About a month ago.
That's right... And you were with Nick here. At the barbershop...
That's right. See... I know your wife.
Is that so?
Yes.
As the number subsides, and the crowd applauds, Herzog appears and addresses Gatsby with whispered intensity.
Mr. Gatsby sir. Mr. Slagle is here...
Herzog indicates SLAGLE, a dark-suited man who stands on distant terrace with three sinister-looking 'associates'.
Gatsby, so besotted with Daisy that he cannot take his ey off her, whispers fiercely...
Not now.
Herzog silently recedes...
A romantic foxtrot strikes up - Trimalchio introduces...
And now...! Dice, Brass Knuckles and Guitars, with: The Foxtrot!
Gatsby turns to Tom, and gestures to Daisy...
Mr. Buchanan, would you mind, terribly?
Tom does indeed look like he minds, but a group of scanti clad girls who cavort gracelessly on the other side of th garden momentarily catch his eye.
Of course not; I think I can keep myself amused.
As Daisy takes Gatsby's arm, she tucks a slim gold pencil into Tom's breast pocket and murmurs...
In case you need to take down any addresses...
As Tom fumes, Gatsby leads Daisy out onto the dance floor
PUSH CLOSE ON: Tom, growing increasingly suspicious...
As Daisy and Gatsby dance, Daisy murmurs thrillingly.
Is all this made entirely from your own imagination?
No... You see you were there all along, in every idea, in every decision... Of course, if anything is not to your liking, we can change it...
It's perfect. From your perfect, irresistible imagination...
Tom and Nick watch Gatsby and Daisy dance. Tom looks arou perplexed by a distant thought.
I wonder where the devil he met Daisy...?
He notices Marlene Moon seductively, secretly watching hi
I'll find you...
He leaves Nick alone. And Nick watches as Gatsby simultaneously leads Daisy from the dance floor...
Daisy runs ahead, playfully hurrying past the low-hanging branches of the massive tree. She disappears inside...
Gatsby follows, but upon entering the secluded, starlit w sees no sign of Daisy.
Then, from out of the shadows, the sparkle of jewels...
Gatsby turns, and Daisy's lips suddenly find his.
A long, still kiss...
Nick is keeping watch, gazing down to his yard and the tr
When Tom suddenly appears...
Have you seen my wife...?
Startled, Nick turns...
Ah... no... Not for awhile.
That's funny. The Senator said he saw her down here.
Tom follows Nick's gaze down toward the tree...
Gatsby and Daisy continue their passionate kissing...
After a moment, Daisy whispers.
I... I wish we could just run away.
Gatbsy is startled.
Run away? Darling, no. Daisy, that... that wouldn't be... respectable.
Tom is still looking to the tree.
You live near here Nick...?
Nick, an overwhelming sense of guilt, indicates vaguely i the direction of the tree.
Just next door.
That so...?
Gatsby continues...
We're going to live here, in this house, together. You and me... Daisy... It's time for you to tell Tom.
CLOSE ON: Nick, a moment of extreme tension as he fears T will investigate further.
SUDDENLY! Their attention is drawn to a commotion on the terrace. Glasses smash, a woman screams, and through the crowd, we see Slagle and associates causing a disturbance
What a circus... Well, if you see her, I'll be looking for her. You tell her.
The hidden lovers speak in intense, hushed tones.
Remember how much fun we used to have? Why can't we just have fun like that again?
Gatsby, frustrated, is about to speak...
But Nick suddenly appears out of the shadows...
Gatsby and Daisy break off, startled...
Oh hello Nicky; we're having a row.
What about?
Daisy glides toward him...
About things... About the future... (trying to be funny) The future of the Colored Empires.
Well, its Tom. He's wandering around the party looking for you.
Daisy flashes Gatsby an over-the-shoulder glance; when, suddenly, Herzog appears and murmurs...
Sir; it's Mr. Slagle; he's quite... emotional.
A tiny, ruffled, moment; then Gatsby elegantly guides Dai toward Nick.
Excuse me. Nick, would you mind?
As Gatsby follows Herzog back toward the castle....
Nick and Daisy return to a party that has become grotesqu drunken girls haphazardly bang drums...
Gatsby disappeared to deal with a dispute of some sort. Daisy waited...
CLOSE ON: Daisy, dejected...
But Gatsby was unable to return.
As Daisy and Nick cross the tattered, streamer-littered d floor CRANE HIGH AND FADE INTO: the library window...
Gatsby sits, solemn in an armchair; with quiet unease wri in shadows across his face.
REVEAL: The ominous silhouette of Wolfsheim, pacing betwe Gatsby and the window; Herzog standing watch...
We catch only a fragment of the conversation.
When these hot headed types appear, I rely on you... But you were not available.. A scene was made... What's going on with you Jay?
HIGH SHOT: A sleek black limo winds quietly towards the g
CRANE DOWN TO DISCOVER: Daisy's face through the limo win her forlorn eyes search for Gatsby behind castle walls...
Where were you?
With Nicky. Mr. Gatsby was showing us the grounds.
Well, he certainly must have strained himself to get that menagerie together...
DAISY'S POV: Ignoring Tom, she looks back to the dark cas
I'd like to know who he is and what he does. And I think I'll make a point of finding out.
As the limo passes through the gates and disappears, Slag and associates are violently ejected by Gatsby's "guards.
CLOSE ON: Atop Gatsby's gate, GATSBY'S COAT OF ARMS READS "Ad Finem Fidelis" ("Faithful to the End").
It is late. Agitated and intense, Gatsby paces by the poo staring out to the green light pulsing across the bay...
Nick descends the stairs, drunk.
Well there you are...! Daisy just left... But she asked me to tell you. She had a wonderful time...
Gatsby is not amused.
She didn't like it.
Of course she did.
No, she didn't like it. She did not have a good time. I feel so far away from her now. It's hard to make her understand.
You mean about the party?
The party!? I couldn't care less about the parties! You see...
She has to tell Tom that she never loved him.
What...?

Yes. Then we can go back to Louisville, to her parents' house - her parents are lovely people old sport - we'll be married there... You see, Daisy and I are going to and start over, just as if it were five years ago.
I wouldn't ask too much of her...
Ask too much?
No.
Gatsby grows suddenly, strangely emotional. He turns his to Nick to compose himself.
I beg your pardon old sport. Its just.. Its so sad because its so hard to make her understand, and--
Jay... You can't repeat the past.
Gatsby wheels around...
Can't repeat the past?
No.
Why of course you can. Of course you can. You'll see. I am going to fix things just the way there were before. Everything's been so... so confused since then...
Gatsby looks out to the green light.
He talked a lot about the past... As if he wanted to recover something...
If I could just get back to the start... If I could just get back to the start I could find it again.
Some vision of himself that he had put into loving Daisy...

head_text.subj: IN THE CLOUDS, AMONG THE STARS, THE IMAGE OF DAISY'S HOUS

text: LOUISVILLE APPEARS, as if frozen in time...
PUSH TOWARD: A wide veranda, strung with banners in suppo of the American war effort, and beyond into a parlour; pr Southern girls and fresh-faced soldiers, dancing, clappin
Five years ago Gatsby found himself at Daisy's house by colossal accident.
Amidst the many revellers, DISCOVER: Daisy, hurrying thro the crowd.
I went to her house first with some of the other officers from Camp Taylor... I'd never been in such a beautiful house before...
Daisy rushes up the steps, and looks back...
At the bottom of the steps, smiling up, is: THE OBJECT OF AFFECTION, Young Gatsby in officer's uniform.
But his uniform his the truth. That he was a penniless young man with only that grand vision of himself.
Daisy's Mother stops her on the steps.
Daisy, don't scamper.
There's so many dashing young officers here, and from such illustrious family's...
CLOSE ON: Gatbsy, watching Daisy...
I always knew that I could climb... But I could only climb if I climbed alone.
Against his better judgement he follows Daisy up...
Checking to make sure no one has seen, Daisy slips quietl through a set of doors, into the conservatory... Gatsby i not far behind... A secret rendezvous.
I knew that, that when I kissed this girl, I would... be forever wed to her...
Daisy throws herself in to Gatsby's arms...
About to kiss, Gatsby is struck by a sudden instinctive thought...
Gatsby remembers...
So I stopped. And I waited... I waited...
Gatsby's eyes drift up...
I waited for a moment longer.
He looks out the dark, crystal windows, beyond the trees. to a staircase of moonlight, climbing up, up, up...
He knew that if he kissed this girl his mind would never again be free to romp like... the mind of God... That falling in love would change his destiny... forever.
And then I just let myself go.
With sudden resolve Gatsby kisses Daisy...
In ravenous embrace, they fall onto the long sofa lounge.
She blossomed for him like a flower...
ECU: Daisy, her lips tremble, eyes wide, breath quickenin
And the incarnation was complete.
The other layers of IMAGERY IN THE CLOUDS MELT AWAY, leav Nick and Gatsby standing by the pool.

I knew it was a great mistake for a man like me to fall in love. A great mistake. I'm only 32... I might still be a great man if I could only forget that I once lost Daisy. But my life, old sport, my life has got to be like this...
He draws a slanting line from the lawn to the stars.
It's got to keep going up.
Gatsby looks to the green light.
She has to go to Tom and tell him she never loved him... I need to give her more time. I just need to give her more time...
He turns to Nick, reassuring both of them.
Don't worry old sport, don't worry. I can protect her here. Good night old sport...
Gatsby heads for his castle, and turns and calls...
You're wrong about the past, old sport...!
Gatsby's POV: The green light across the bay.
You're wrong.
The first day of spring; out the window, birds chirp.
Nick is writing and reading aloud...
There had been music from my neighbor's all summer. In his blue gardens, men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings and the laughter and the stars...
He struggles for a more poetic phrasing...
Laughter... No... No... Among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars...
(that's the one) But after Tom and Daisy visit...
Gatsby's castle cuts a grave silhouette against a stormy
There were no more parties...
His lights flicker and go out.
Gatsby's lights went out one by one.
At the gates flashbulbs flash! Hordes of press have gathe
Daisy visited discreetly. But...
As the gates creak open, Daisy's limo slides up the drive
The very same fame that had once been a source of satisfaction to Jay Gatsby, became... a threat.
As the reporters crowd the limo, shouting questions...
Locked away deep in the castle, Gatsby and Daisy make lov
At the end of the wharf, Gatsby and Daisy look out across bay, watching as the sun slides into the horizon, and the green light pulses...
CLOSE ON: Daisy. She leans to Gatsby and whispers...
I don't want to go home.
Gatsby hold her tighter.
Then don't.
Long shafts of light cut through the high, empty windows.
WIDE SHOT: An OLD EUROPEAN WOMAN crosses the ballroom, te tray in hand. The room is lined with thuggish, dark-suite men.
We hear a phone conversation between Nick and Gatsby...
I've been meaning to call you up. I'm sorry, I've been... so busy.
Is everything alright?
An unshaven Gatsby in trousers and a black silk robe sits a large arm-chair, under a vast wall of magnificent paintings. He hunches over the phone...
Yes... Daisy and I are very much in love.
I hear you fired all your servants?

Daisy comes over sometimes in the afternoons and I wanted some people who wouldn't gossip... until we decided what we're going to do... You see these two towns are pretty close together. And it gets in the papers... You understand?
They're some people Wolfsheim wanted to do something for.
Herzog stands in the shadows; and the old European woman pours coffee and then recedes...
What's the difference as long as they can cook and make beds...?
Nick holds the phone close to his ear, trying to hear Gat above the din around him; his work is piled high...
Gatsby whispers into the phone...
Nick... Daisy's ready. Shes ready. But there's just one thing. She's requested that you and Miss Baker be there, at lunch tomorrow, at her house... Will you come, old sport?
Daisy needs you. I... We need you. Will you come old sport?
PUSH IN ON: Nick. A decision looms...
WIDE SHOT: The imposing Buchanan mansion bakes in the sun
CLOSE ON: Tom lighting a fat Cuban from a chrome lighter.
You know, I read somewhere that the sun's getting hotter every year...
Blue cigar smoke wafts over the clearing of plates...
Or wait a minute; it's the opposite...
Tom stands and strolls to the open French window...
The sun is getting colder every year...
Daisy grips a wine glass in her trembling hand; her eyes terrified, perspiration forms on her upper lip. She glanc to Gatsby, who stares resolutely from across the table.
CLOSE ON: A perspiring Nick. He glances from Daisy to Gat
The tension is excruciating.
Out the window Tom catches sight of a sailboat across the bay.
How I'd like to be out on that bay today.
CLOSE ON: Gatsby. He looks up. Beyond the sailboat, he ca see the outline of his castle.
I'm right across from you.
Right there.
So you are.
Gatsby slowly stands and walks behind Daisy.
Every night I can see that light at the end of your dock, blinking.
What light?
Gatsby gently moves his hand over Daisy's...
You see, Mr. Buchanan, I wanted to be close-- Daisy and I--
With sudden intensity Daisy stands!
(on the verge of tears) It's so hot...
Agitated, she sweeps toward the sideboard.
Everything's so confused.
She plucks a cigarette from a carved box, and fumbles wit the paperweight-sized lighter.
What'll we do with ourselves this afternoon...? And the day after that... (she snaps it again) ...and for the next thirty years?
Let's all go to town! Who wants to go to town?
Her nervous hands drop the lighter, which crashes to the mahogany floor. All but Tom recoil in shock.
Town!? Women... They get these notions...
Gatsby walks to Daisy... As Tom puffs, Gatsby retrieves t lighter in one hand, and with his other gently guides Dai trembling hand... In that moment, their eyes tenderly mee
Daisy...
(as if they are alone) You look so cool. You always look so cool, like the advertisement of the man... in Times Square...
CLOSE ON: Tom, his jaw tightening.
The man in the cool, beautiful, shirts.
CAMERA FLOATS TOWARD TOM... He violently snuffs his cigar
She had told Gatsby that she loved him - and Tom had seen...
SUDDENLY Tom explodes!
Let's go to town! I'm perfectly willing...! That's a marvelous idea! Henri! Have the car brought around immediately!
Just like that? Can't anyone at least have a cigarette?
We've smoked all through lunch.
Oh, let's have fun. It's too hot to fuss.
It was your great idea Daisy. Why don't we!? We'll all go to town!
Daisy doesn't budge.
I've changed my mind...
You brute.
(a dangerous intensity) You've got me all excited, and now you don't want to go? We'll get a great big room at the Plaza, a cold bucket of ice, and some whiskey... It will be fun.
Fine. Have it your own way, Tom... Come on, Jordan.
As she and Jordan rush past Tom, down the hall, Tom turns calmly to Gatsby.
Will you join us, Mr. Gatsby?
Then turns and calls to Henri...
Henri! Get some whiskey! Two bottles, wrapped in a towel.
CLOSE ON: Shoes shifting on gravel. Gatsby and Nick stand uncomfortably on the drive, waiting for Tom and the women
BANG! Tom storms out wrapping a quart bottle in a towel.
Daisy and Jordan follow.
Mr. Gatsby! Would you be good enough to take my coupГ©? And I'll drive everyone else in your circus wagon.
I don't think there's much gas, old sport.
Gatsby looks to Daisy, a burning stare.
(looks at the gauge) Plenty of gas. And if we run out, then we'll stop at a drug store. I hear you can buy anything at a drug store nowadays... (savagely eyes Gatsby) Isn't that right, Mr. Gatsby?
A moment of sharp tension; Daisy wrenches from Tom's arm.
You take Nick and Jordan, Tom!
She slips quickly into the coupГ©...
We'll meet you at the Plaza! I'll be the man on the corner smoking two cigarettes...
Gatsby's and Tom's eyes flash; a harsh, competitive glanc
Tom lunges into the Duesenberg, slams the gears and lurch away, leaving Gatsby, Daisy, and the coupГ© in the dust.
Tom throttles forward, watching Jordan and Nick...
You think I'm pretty dumb, don't you? But I have a-- an almost second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. And I've made a small investigation of this fellow.
And you found he was an Oxford man?
Oxford, New Mexico! He wears a pink suit for Christ's sake!
With that, Tom shifts gears and the Duesenberg rockets on
HIGH AND WIDE: The Duesenberg tears into the Valley...
We're almost out of gas Tom...
SCRREEECH! Tom slams the breaks and the Duesenberg slides a stop at Wilson's...
Wilson doesn't budge. He's staring with sickly eyes at th giant billboard of Dr. T. J. Eckleberg.
Wilson! Wilson! What are you waiting for!? Let's have some gas...
Do I have to do it myself?
I'm sick. I'm all run down. I need money bad... My wife and I want to go West.
Your wife does...?
Tom glances up to the window above the garage. Myrtle's f badly bruised, stares back. Tom clocks this, and hesitate
Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His mistress and wife, an hour ago so secure, were both slipping from his control...
I just got wised-up to something funny the last two days. She's goin' whether she wants to or not.
Tom isn't listening... He sees the coupe approaching at h speed, threatening to leave him in the dust!
What do I owe you!?
Dollar twenty.
The blue coupГ© flashes by. Tom glances back to Myrtle... then jumps into the Duesenberg.
You can have the car! I'll send it around tomorrow!
He throws coins into the dirt for Wilson to collect. Then floors the gas and peels out after the coupГ©!
VRRROOMM! The cars roar neck-and-neck, veering, swerving skidding PERILOUSLY close.
As Tom and Gatsby shoot dangerous glances at one another, Daisy waves carefree back to Tom....
PAN UP: The cars tear over the Queensboro Bridge, toward glimmering, golden city...
CRACK! CRACK! CRACK! Shards of ice spilt off from a hunk bell-boy makes ice-cubes...
That's enough...
The room is large and stifling hot, it has been filled wi huge ice buckets in an attempt to cool it. Gatsby, Tom, N Daisy and Jordan are bathed in a thin sheen of perspirati
Open another window.
There aren't any more.
Then telephone for an axe...
Forget about the heat. You make it worse by crabbing about it.
Why not let her alone, old sport?
That's a great expression of yours, isn't it?
What is?
Tom turns to Gatsby...
'Old sport'. Where'd you pick it up?
Now see here, Tom; if you're going to make personal remarks I won't stay here one minute.
Gatsby's foot beats a restless tattoo; Tom eyes him sudde
Mr. Gatsby, I understand you're an Oxford man.
No, not exactly.
Oh yes, I understand you went to Oxford.
Yes - I went there.
Tom's laugh is incredulous and insulting.
Sure; the man in the pink suit went to Oxford!
Tom...!
Gatsby stands.
(slow, intense) I told you I went there.
I heard you, but I'd like to know when.
You'd like to know when....? It was in nineteen-nineteen, I only stayed five months. That's why I can't exactly call myself an Oxford man.
Tom glances around to see if the others mirror his disbel But they are all looking at Gatsby.
You see, it was an opportunity they gave to some of the officers who actually fought in the war.
Nick can't help but smile.
I wanted to get up and slap Gatsby on the back.
I'll make you a drink Tom, then you won't seem so stupid to yourself...
But Tom's not done yet.
Wait a minute, I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.
Go on. Please Mr. Buchanan, go on.
What kind of a row are you trying to cause in my house anyhow?
They are out in the open at last and Gatsby is content.
He isn't causing a row; you're causing a row. Please have a little self-control!

Self-control! I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife? Well, if that's the idea you can count me out... See, nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions and next you know they'll throw everything overboard and we'll have intermarriage between black and white!
We're all white here, Tom.
Your wife doesn't love you. She's never loved you. She loves me!
You must be crazy.
No, old sport. See, she never loved you... She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting. It was a terrible, terrible mistake, but in her heart she never loved anyone but me!
We should go...
Daisy and I have nothing to hide...
Jay let's go, please...!
Sit down Daisy!
Yes, Daisy, please sit down.
Tom's voice gropes unsuccessfully for the paternal note.
What's been going on? I want to hear all about it.
I just told you what's been going on; its been going on for five years...!
Tom turns to Daisy sharply.
You've been seeing him for five years?
Not seeing. No, we couldn't; but both of us loved each other all that time, old sport, and you didn't know. I used to laugh sometimes, to think that you didn't know...

Oh - that's all; you're crazy! I can't speak about what happened five years ago, because I didn't know Daisy then - but I'll be damned if I see how you got within a mile of her unless you brought the groceries to the back door. But all the rest of that's a god-damned lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she loves me now.
Tom starts to make himself a drink...
No...
She does, though... And what's more, I love Daisy too. Once in a while I go off on a spree, but I always come back, and in my heart I love her all the time...
You're revolting...
Daisy's voice drops an octave lower, filling the room wit thrilling scorn...
Do you know why we left Chicago...? I'm surprised they didn't treat you to the story of that little spree.
Gatsby walks over and stands beside Daisy.
That's all over now. Just tell him the truth, that you never loved him; and all this... all this pain will be wiped out forever.
Daisy looks at Gatsby blindly.
Why, how could I love him, possibly?
You never loved him.
Daisy hesitates; too late, she realizes what she is doing
I never loved him.
That's right...
Not at Kapiolani?
No.
(a husky tenderness) Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry...? Daisy? Never?
Please don't.
Daisy...
Her voice is cold, but the anger is gone.
There, Jay.
She trembles as she looks to Gatsby...
You want too much! I love you now; isn't that enough? I can't help what's past. (begins to sob) I did love him once; but I loved you too.
(shocked, uncomprehending) You loved me too?
Even that's a lie. She didn't know you were alive. There are things between Daisy and me that you'll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.
The words seem to bite physically into Gatsby.
I want to speak to Daisy alone. She's all excited now...
Even alone I can't say I never loved Tom. It wouldn't be true.
Of course it wouldn't.
Daisy turns to her husband.
As if it mattered to you.
Of course it matters. I'm going to take better care of you from now on.
You're not taking care of her any more! Daisy's leaving you.
Nonsense.
(with visible effort) I am, though.
She's not leaving me; and certainly not for a common swindler!
Tom's words suddenly lean down over Gatsby.
Mr. Gatsby, who exactly are you anyhow? You see, I have made a small investigation into your affairs... You're one of Meyer Wolfsheim's bunch.
Tom turns to the others and speaks rapidly.
See, he and this Wolfsheim bought up a lot of 'drug stores' and sold bootlegged alcohol over the counter!
What about it, old sport?
Don't call me `old sport!' This drug store business is just small change compared to the bonds stunt you and Wolfsheim have got going on now.
Well your friend Walter Chase isn't too proud to come in on it.
I've been giving that some thought. How does a reputable banker like Walter Chase find himself up to his eyeballs in debt to a little kike like Wolfsheim?
It's called `greed,' old sport.
That's right; you've got half of Wall Street out there swilling your free booze at that fun park every weekend...
I'm surprised he hasn't tried to drag you in...
Nick looks away sharply. Tom registers this.
My God, he has...
He's got nothing to do with--
With your little racket...
Daisy... Can't you see who this guy is? With his house and his parties and his fancy clothes; he's just a front for Wolfsheim, a gangster, to get his claws into respectable folk like Walter...!
(a vicious sneer) The only respectable thing about you, old sport, is your money, that's it, and now I've just as much as you; so that means we're equal!!
Tom smiles with smug, condescending scorn.
Oh no, no, we're different; I am, (gesturing at Nick and
They are... (now at Daisy)
we're all different from you - we were born different, it's in our blood, and nothing you do, or say, or steal or dream up, can ever change that... And a girl like Daisy will never...!
Gatsby explodes with terrifying rage.
SHUT UP! SHUT UP! SHUTTT UP!!!!
Shock jolts the room. We float toward Gatsby. His rage-fi eyes stare into the void, as, with all his willpower, he restrains himself from ripping Tom apart...
Gatsby looked, in that moment... as if he had "killed a man."
Tom snorts a dismissive laugh.
That's right Mr. Gatsby, show us those fine Oxford manners...
Gatsby recovers and turns to Diasy, who is trembling in t corner, on the verge of tears.
My sincerest apologies. I... I seem to have lost my temper.
Struggling for self control, Gatsby turns toward her as i Tom suddenly no longer exists.
Daisy darling... None of this has any consequence. Don't listen to him Daisy.
Daisy blanches; Gatsby, now desperate, babbles incoherent
We're going back   to Louisville to be married. Then   we're going to live together in   our house; it's--
There is a feeling of excruciating unease in the room.
CLOSE ON: Nick.
He began talking excitedly, denying everything... But with every word Daisy was drawing further and further into herself, until only the dead dream fought on...
Please Tom; I can't stand this anymore!
Daisy is staring, terrified, courage gone; she looks to T
You two start on home...
In Mr. Gatsby's car.
Daisy is alarmed now.
Go on. He won't annoy you. I think he realizes that his little flirtation... is over.
Daisy, hysterical, runs from the room; Gatsby pursues her
Daisy...!
Daisy and Gatsby are gone. A terrible silence fills the r Tom begins wrapping the unopened whiskey bottle in the to
Want any of this? Jordan? Nick? Nick?
What?
Want any?
No... I just remembered - today's my birthday. I'm thirty.
Tom mutters as he pours himself a drink...
Happy birthday...
Nick is staring out the window, lost in thought...
Thirty - the promise of a decade of loneliness...
NICK'S POV: To the setting sun and the Queensboro Bridge.
The formidable stroke of thirty died away, as Gatsby and Daisy drove on through the cooling twilight, towards death...
MYRTLE FLIES PAST CAMERA as Wilson drags her across the r
God knows everything you've been doing!
Grabbing his wife's hair he presses her face to the windo
You might fool me but you can't fool God!
OVER WILSON'S SHOULDER, we see with shock, that he is loo at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleberg.
God sees everything!
Below the Eckleberg sign a train thunders through the lev crossing.
The final carriage clears to reveal Gatsby's yellow car waiting on the other side of the crossing.
CLOSE ON: Myrtle seeing the yellow car; a desperate whisp
(thinking its Tom) He's here...
WHACK! Myrtle gives a sudden backhand to Wilson's face as twists from his grasp!
Standing outside his restaurant, the owner, MICHAELIS see Myrtle rush out of the garage shouting hysterically.
Stop, Tom, please, stop!
SUDDENLY! Myrtle appears in the headlights of Gatsby's ca
ECU: The sleeve of the pink suit and the 'Daisy' signet r as Gatsby's hand on the wheel tries to veer away...!
BUT the car STRIKES Myrtle!

head_text.subj: SLOW MOTION, TERRIBLE, NIGHTMARISH, EXPRESSIONISTIC IMAGE

text: Glass shattering, blood splattering, Daisy screaming, Myrtle's body flying through the air, her pearls showerin the night like a thousand new stars...
THUMP. Her torn open body hits the ground.
CLOSE ON: The giant billboard, the towering eyes of Dr. T Eckleberg, watching everything...

head_text.subj: DISSOLVE THROUGH THE WHITES OF THE EYES TO

text: CLOSE ON: The coupe's blinding headlights.
As the coupГ© nears, Nick, Tom and Jordan see the commoti
Wreck...! Good. Wilson will have a little business at last... Let's take a look..
Must we?
Just a look.
The dim garage is lit only by a swinging yellow globe.
Wilson stands on the raised threshold of his office, sway and wailing a high, horrible call.
O, my Ga-od! O, my Ga-od!
A crush of gawking spectators speak in hushed tones.
CUT TO: Tom pushing through the crowd.
CLOSE ON: He stops, and makes a harsh sound...
MYRTLE'S BODY, wrapped in a blanket, lies on a work table
Tom bends over it, shocked, motionless.
CUT TO: Nick, watching Tom's reaction.
A POLICEMAN stands next to Tom taking down names.
Sir. Sir, I'm gonna have to ask you to step away--
Get off me...! (regains his composure) I'm fine. I'm fine.
You knew her?
(a long pause) No... Not really...
Well then I have to ask you to step back.
What happened...?
She ran out `inna road. Son-of-a- bitch didn't even stopus car.
A well-dressed African American man steps near.
I saw it! It was a yellow car; big yellow car.
CUT TO: Tom; a slow realization.
PUSH IN: On Nick; a disbelieving horror.
The Greek restaurant owner MICHAELIS pipes up.
Yeah, a big yellow duezy; custom job.
Some of this conversation has reached Wilson; suddenly sighting Tom, he moves toward him with a cry...
You don't have to tell me what kind of car it was! I know what kind of car it was!
Tom, realizing the danger, moves quickly and seizes Wilso
(a soothing gruffness) Pull yourself together...
Wilson, distraught, almost collapses, but Tom holds him upright and pushes him into:
Tom sets Wilson down and whispers intensely.
Listen, I just got here from New York. I was bringing you the coupГ©. That yellow car wasn't mine, do you hear? I haven't seen it all afternoon.
The policeman follows and turns suspiciously to Tom.
What color's your car?
Blue, a coupГ©; we've come straight from New York.
Yeah, they just stopped...
The policeman accepts, suspicious still...
Alright... Blue.
In the relative calm of the office, Wilson's clouded, desperate eyes look up at Tom.
Who owns the yella' car...?
(a tiny pause) Fella named Gatsby; he's a crook, George. Gives those parties the papers are always talking about...
Maybe he was the one foolin' with Myrtle; maybe that's why he killed her...?
Yeah. Maybe. Guy like that, who knows...
Wilson starts sobbing again.
Oh, Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od!
He rests his head on Tom's shoulder...
Tom consoles Wilson and then whispers...
Gatsby. Something outta be done about a fella like that. He'll pay... Oh, he'll pay...
CLOSE ON: Tom driving. He sobs...
The goddamn coward didn't even stop his car...
Jordan and Nick sit silently beside Tom; he turns to them triumphantly accusing...
You gonna defend him now, huh?
The coupe drifts slowly up the drive.
As they walk up the stone staircase, Tom disposes of the situation in a few brisk phrases.
I'll telephone for a taxi, Nick. Come in and have some supper while you wait...
Tom opens the door.
No thanks. I'll wait outside.
Tom stares at Nick, absorbing his disdain.
What is the matter with you?
Tom snorts and goes in; Jordan puts her hand on Nick's ar
Won't you come in, Nick?
No... thanks.
It's only half past nine...
No. I think I've had enough... Of everyone.
CLOSE ON: Jordan; she gives Nick a long, hurt look...
But Nick stares decisively back; after a moment he turns sharply and walks off. Dejected, Jordan sweeps inside...
As Nick's feet crunch upon the white gravel of the drive, is startled by a voice from the shadows...
Hello old sport...
Cautiously, Nick approaches the hedge. The closer he gets more certain he becomes: Gatsby is hiding, just below Dai window. His pace quickens.
What are you doing!?
Just sitting here...
Yes, I can see that.
Did you see any trouble out on the road?
Trouble!? That woman you ran down is dead Jay!
I thought so... I told Daisy I
Daisy? Do you hear yourself--
Its better that the shock should come all at once--
What's wrong with you!? How could you!?
Please... Keep your voice down, old sport.
Tom was right! You're nothing but a goddamn coward!
Keep your voice down... There. Was. No. Point. In. Stopping.
NO POINT!?
It, it killed her instantly. I--
Yes, I was there. I saw! It ripped her open!
Panicked, Gatsby grabs Nick, trying to explain...
I understand-- It was... my fault. This woman just rushed out, as if she wanted to speak to us... It all happened so quickly. She-- I... tried-- to turn the wheel.
She?
SUDDENLY! The CREAK of a door opening. A shaft of light..
Henri emerges.
AN INTERMINABLE moment. Gatsby and Nick hold their breath
Finally, Henri goes back in.
CLOSE ON: Nick, a realization.
It was Daisy?
Finally, and very slowly, Gatsby admits.
You see, after we left New York, she was very nervous. She thought driving would steady her. But this woman, she just rushed out at us.
CUT TO: We replay the violent accident, this time fully REVEALING that it was Daisy behind the wheel...
It all happened so quickly. It wasn't her fault...
It was my fault. I should have taken the wheel...
No one must know. Promise me. No one. Promise me.
Jay-- You shouldn't be here. You should get out of here.
Gatsby gazes back to the house...

No. No. No. I'm going to wait. I'll wait all night if necessary. You see, Daisy's locked herself in her room, and she's going to turn her light off and on again if he tries to bother her about that unpleasantness this afternoon. If he tries ANY brutality whatsoever--
Tom won't touch her. He's not even thinking about her...
Oh, I don't trust him, old sport. I don't trust him.
Nick considers the light at the end of the terrace.
Alright. Alright... You wait here. I'll see if there's any commotion.
Would you do that for me? Thank you. Thank you, old sport.
Nick skirts the terrace...
Rounding the corner, Nick, unseen in the shadows, can see and Daisy sitting at one end of the vast dining table, a plate of cold chicken and two bottles of ale between them
As Tom speaks intently and earnestly at Daisy, his hand f gently upon hers and she nods tiredly in agreement...
Its going to be all right...
Then, very slowly, Daisy lays her head on Tom's shoulder.
CLOSE ON: Nick, shocked... angry.
DISCOVER: Nick sitting, drinking from a bottle of whiskey
The sound of a car coming up Gatsby's drive...
CLOSE ON: Gatsby cleaning blood from the Duesenberg's fen
Nick appears, coming across the yard.
Jay? Everything alright...?
Exhausted, Gatsby turns...

Oh, hello, old sport. Yes, yes, everything's just fine... About four o'clock she came to the window; she stood there... Then, well, she turned out the light... So... (beckons to the car) Give me a hand will you old sport?
CLOSE ON: Nick.
I should have told him what I had just seen. But all I could manage was...
Jay... You oughtta go away.
He helps Gatsby cover the car.
Tonight. They'll trace your car.
(as if Nick is crazy) Go away? I can't leave now. Not tonight.
Do you understand that a woman has been killed--?
Nick follows him from the garage toward the house.
Daisy's going to call in the morning. Then we'll make plans, to go away together.
But Jay she--
Sensing Nick's tone, Gatsby cuts him off and banishes all doubt with intense certainty.
She just needs time to think... (he continues, calm) She'll call. In the morning. She just needs time to think.
She just needs to think. She's going to call in the morning.
Gatsby smiles that smile of endless possibility...
He turns to go in but stops.
Wait up with me? The suns almost up...
That was the night he finally told me the truth. All of it.
Gatsby's voice echoes through the empty halls of his vast lonely mansion as he confesses...
You know, I thought for awhile I had a lot of things... But the truth is... I'm empty.
I suppose that's why I make things up about myself... But I`ve wanted to tell you the whole story for a long time... You see. I grew up, terribly, terribly poor, old sport. My folks were, well--
As Gatbsy continues, Nick's V.O. FADES UP:
He revealed his humble beginnings, his transformative voyage with Dan Cody, the war, Oxford, and how he'd joined Wolfsheim in the business...
In the silvery pre-dawn, Nick and Gatsby trail slowly tow the end of the dock.
It was also that night that I became aware of Gatsby's... extraordinary gift for hope.
...I can't describe to you how surprised I was to find out that I loved her, old sport. And that she loved me too.
A gift that I have never found in any other person...
I never realized just how extraordinary a nice girl could be.
And which it is not likely I shall ever find again.
I thought out my life with Daisy in it, trying to figure out how we could marry and struggle along on so many dollars a month...
Finally, Nick is able to ask:
What was in the letter?
Gatsby reaches the end of the wharf and looks to the gree light across the bay...
The truth, the reason why after the war, I hadn't been able to return--
In the clouds overhead, the IMAGE OF DAISY, in the bathtu with the DISSOLVING LETTER... And now, we can see what Ga wrote in that fateful, last letter: "Daisy, the truth is. I'm penniless."
I asked her to wait until I'd made something of myself. But-- She was young, there was so much pressure.
The IMAGE of Daisy fades...
You see, I felt married to her... That was all.
It had all been for her. The house the parties, everything.
CLOSE ON: A hand takes a revolver from a desk drawer...
It is Wilson.
FLOAT: Toward the window behind him...
WE SEE the staring eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleberg.
God sees everything.
Nick and Gatsby are finishing breakfast.
Mr. Gatsby sir, excuse me, Chicago calling sir.
Now now. Keep it open. For a personal call...
A personal call? Of course.
The GARDENER comes to the foot of the steps.
I'm going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby.
Not today. It's so beautiful.
You know, old sport, I've never used that pool all summer?
Gatsby enthusiastically heads down the stairs...
Let's go for a swim. I'll have the phone transferred to the pool...
As Gatsby heads toward the pool, Nick checks his watch...
Jay, I've got to go. I have to work.
I understand... Well, I'll walk you out.
Gatsby leads Nick toward the side gate. At the gate...
I'll call you up.
Do, old sport, please do.
I suppose Daisy'll call too.
I suppose so... Well... Goodbye.
Nick lingers... Then they shake hands and he starts away. Just before he reaches the hedge he turns back and calls:
They're a rotten crowd! You're worth the whole damn bunch put together!
First Gatsby nods politely, and then his face breaks into that radiant and understanding smile.
I was always glad I said that... It was the only compliment I ever paid him.
CLOSE ON: Nick, tired, sick-looking.
That morning, Wall Street boomed, its usual golden roar... But I wasn't worth a decent stroke of work. I waited for Gatsby to call with news...
Gatsby heads for the pool, ready to swim...
While he waited for Daisy...
SPLASH! Gatsby dives gracefully into the pool.
We see Gatsby from below, body gliding through clear wate
CLOSE ON: A white telephone on a ivory plinth.
REVEAL: Daisy, considering the phone...
A gun dangles from a hand.
Wilson's scarecrow shadow ripples across the lawn.
Gatsby's head breaks the smooth, green surface of the wat
SUDDENLY! BRRRING!!! The phone rings...
Gatsby smiles and gazes across toward the green light, to Daisy.
PULL FOCUS: Atop the monumental stairs, Wilson, raises a
CLOSE ON: Gatsby - a moment of strangled, startled, wonde His lips form a final, breathless...
Daisy...
Then his face hardens as he slowly falls backwards... SPL
Placing his gun in his mouth Wilson pulls the trigger.
A SILENT IMAGE of Nick screaming into the phone.
Daisy's hand rests on the phone... She never called.
Gatsby's body descends through a cloud of blood...
After all these years, I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day as an endless drill...
Looking up from the bottom of the pool we see a crowd of staring faces and the pop of flashbulbs through water...
...of police and photographers and tabloid reporters.
The headlines were a nightmare... They pinned everything on Gatsby.

head_text.subj: THROUGH THE WATER HEADLINES FADE IN

text: The affair with Myrtle...
The hit and run...
Everything.
ECU: Gatsby's ghostly face...
And there was nothing I could say except the one unutterable fact that none of it was true...
PULL TO REVEAL: Gatsby, immaculately attired, is laid out a silver coffin and crowded by a crush of policemen, photographers and reporters...
TOP SHOT: Servants carry endless luggage through the hall down the stairs, and out the front door...
BRRIIING!!! A phone rings OFF-SCREEN.
At the bottom of the stairs, DISCOVER: Daisy and Pammy.
(explains to Pammy) Daddy's taking care of his two favorite girls...
But where are we going?
Just for a little trip. Just you, me, and daddy...
Tom appears beside Daisy.
We should go.
BRRIIING!!! Finally, at the top of the stairs, Henri answ
Buchanan residence.
DISCOVER: Nick sits atop the deco stairs, telephone in ha
Gatsby coffin is directly below...
May I speak to Mrs. Buchanan? It's Mr. Carraway, her cousin...
Madame is not available.
Well, when you see her, will you tell her, the funeral's tomorrow?
Henri looks down to Tom, who shoots a "we're not here" lo
I'm sorry, but... They have gone away.
Gone away...? Do you know when they'll be back.
No.
Please, I know she would want to be there. If you could just get a message to her--
I have no further information monsieur. Au revoir.
CLICK. Henri abruptly hangs up.
Hello...? Hello!?
The Buchanan family exits...
As Nick slowly, bitterly hangs up the telephone...
They were careless people, Tom and Daisy. They smashed up things and people and then retreated back into their money and their vast carelessness...
He looks to the throng of press swarming like vultures ar Gatsby's casket. Seized by fury, he snaps and screams as advances down the stairs!
GET OUT! ALL OF YOU OUT! GET OUT...!!!
Time has passed. Nick sits on the steps slouched against rail. He looks down to Gatsby's still face, sad, alone...
I rang, I wrote, I implored...

head_text.subj: THE CAMERA PUSHES SLOWLY DOWN TOWARD GATSBY

text: But not a single one of the sparkling hundreds who had enjoyed his hospitality all summer, attended the funeral...
ECU: Gatsby.
And from Daisy, not even a flower.
Distraught and exhausted, Nick's eyes slowly close...
I was all he had; the only one who cared...
Nick is sound asleep on the couch, his typewriter and doz of type-filled pages in front of him. Clearly, he has bee writing all night...
The Doctor enters. He looks tenderly to Nick, and picks u loose page from the floor...
Its winter now.
The city is blanketed by an unforgiving, cold grey sky...
After Gatsby's death, New York was haunted for me...
DISCOVER: Nick, a tumult of anger, grief and despair, wandering unshaven through a Fifth Avenue crowd...
That city... My once golden... shimmering mirage, now made me sick.
DRIFT TOWARD: Gatsby's castle, ghostly in the moonlight.
On my last night in New York... I returned to that huge, incoherent house once more.
Very drunk, Nick trails over broken relics of lost grande through rooms that have been stripped...
Wolfsheim's 'associates' had cleaned the place out...
ALL AROUND NICK: Ghostly images from Nick's memory - from those glittering parties, haunting snatches of music, laughter and conversation, imagery - mixing and FADING IN OUT...
He threw all those parties hoping she would wander in one night...
Its like an amusement park...
But how do you live her all alone?
She makes it look so splendid, don't you think, old sport?
Music! And then we can dance all night...
Will you come old sport? We... need you.
I wish it could always be like this...
It will be...
Nick wanders out as a light rain beings to fall.
I remembered how we had all come to Gatsby's, and guessed at his corruption... While he had stood before us concealing an incorruptible dream...
A FINAL MEMORY: Gatsby and Daisy together on the dance- floor... Daisy leans in and whispers happily to Gatsby...
Its perfect... From your perfect, irresistible imagination.
Nick stumbles along the dock; the rain falling steadily n
The moon rose higher... And as I stood there, brooding on the old, unknown world, I thought of Gatsby's wonder when he first picked out the green light at the end of Daisy's dock.
Nick looks to the end of the dock, where he first saw Gat that warm summer night...
He had come such a long way...
And suddenly, shimmering ghostly through the rain, Gatsby silhouette can be seen once more, gazing out across the b
And his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it.
Gatsby turns back towards Nick, and smiles...
He did not know that it was already behind him...
Nick smiles back.
Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year, recedes before us...
PUSH PAST GATSBY: Out over the water, toward the green li eternally pulsing at the end of Daisy's dock...
It eluded us then, but that's no matter - tomorrow we will run faster...
Gatsby reaches out--
Stretch out our arms farther... And one fine morning...
As we PUSH PAST Gatbsy's outstretched hand, THE OPENING I RETURNS: The green light pulsing in the abstract dark...
Nick's final words appear as TYPE ON THE SCREEN.
So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly, into the past.
Nick pulls a final page from his typewriter, sets the pag top of his completed manuscript and we clearly see the ti
Nick considers this and then handwrites:
The green light. It pulses one last time... Then, fades t BLACK.
